review_title: Wonderful Place to Jump-start Your Career!
pros: WellSpan is a great place to work with a great benefits package for full-time employees. That said, the company values its employees and constantly invests in them through professional development, promoting WITHIN the company, and not going outside the organization to hire. Furthermore, WellSpan provides its employees with a flexible work schedule including the ability to work from home. My work-life balance is fulfilling and I am not reprimanded for setting boundaries when it comes to work. Lastly, the pay is great! I began working here after a 2-year sabbatical to take care of my son during the pandemic after losing my job and they did not use that against me during the interviewing process! Lastly, CEO/Leadership communications is frequent and transparency on financial stewardship and where WellSpan stands post-pandemic is always a necessity, especially with wanting to know that my job is secure.
cons: WellSpan is known for collaboration, which is great, but it can stall project progress. The bureaucracy and office politics can be paralyzing, especially for such a large healthcare organization. Additionally, the organization is heading towards being insights-driven but isn't quite there yet. There's quite a bit of ambiguity around data and data storytelling, but we are on our way!

job_title: Licensed Mental Health Professional in Lancaster, PA
pros:
great healthcare benefits
Pay is good
cons:
Get comfotable, I've got a lot to offer:

An insidious big-corporate culture has completely creeped in since Philhaven was acquired by WellSpan in 2016, followed by the inevitable arrival of The Consultants in 2018. There's barely an attempt to hide the full-on revenue focus niw. "Non-Profit" in name only. 

Therapists are not trusted with clinical judgment or caseload management. LEAN has been embraced as the holy grail to replace those professional skills: Centralized services that can't recognize and respond to individualized needs, standard work processes written for everything, zero control of your own schedules, so clients, now called "patients", are crammed in back-to-back every 45 minutes to "maximize RVUs" (expect to have 12+ sessions a day). Caseload flow is (un)managed to an untenable capacity, resulting in compromised quality of care for clients. Session length was shortened from 45 minutes to 40 minutes...still the same billing code and allows them to squeeze another session into your workday. Concurrent Documentation is policy so you don't need time outside of sessions to document. 

Epic for EMR...death by 1000 clicks! Even worse, because it's primary use is medical, behavioral health had to adapt its own standard language to use medical language. When both fields happen to share a particular word or phrase that have different meanings or applications, the medical one was adopted in the EMR and the behavioral health language was changed to something else that often seemed like an IT person made it up on the fly. 

A new "innovative" Pillars of Care structure was adopted for Outpatient Services that now requires clients to travel to one of two locations for an intake (York or Ephrata) and then engage in Transitional Care (therapy groups), until an individual therapist becomes available. There's little-to-no acknowledgement of what a client may have said they wanted and needed when they sought care. 
LEAN it is...like a Ford assembly line. There's so much more. But, the bottom-line is that, if you want a hamster-wheel job, work here. If you want a meaningful, fulfilling profession, don't.

review_title: Wellspan is good, but the Spiritual Care department is disorganized and underfunded.
pros:
Wellspan treats its employees well and offers a decent stipend by chaplain residency standards. It also offers a $2400 stipend for meals in the cafeteria (but not the Starbucks cafe elsewhere in the hospital). Employees are relatively happy and the standard of care is quite high. Most staff are open to the presence of a chaplain and include us in their teamwork, including in crisis situations.

The Spiritual Care department managers are open and friendly, and are willing to accept criticism.
cons:
Unfortunately, the Spiritual Care department is underfunded and often disorganized. 

My cohort of residents experienced serious over-work, often at the hospital for 60-70 hours/week, instead of the normal 45-50 one expects from a chaplain residency. Part of this was due to the complications of covid. It is also partly due to a budget that only includes 1 staff chaplain for a 700 bed, level 1 trauma hospital. 

Yet we had very little support from management. There was very little willingness to explore creative ways to reduce the workload of the residents. 
 The manager/educator that directly runs the residents also provides very poor leadership both within the CPE coursework as an educator and administratively as a manager. This leads to a lot of frustration and missed opportunities. 

Having said all that, I am glad that I did this residency. But I would not have survived if not for the support my cohort provided each other, in the absence of structural support.

job_title: 6 Job Titles In 20 Years of Employment in York, PA
pros: WellSpan Health values its employees by offering competitive salaries, excellent benefits and a committment to work-life balance.  When making decisions about its services, WellSpan Health considers the health care needs of the community, the current economic climate in health care in general and the welfare of its employees.  It's never an easy juggling act, but WellSpan does an exceptional job!
cons: Because WellSpan Health is such a fantastic employer, people tend to work for them for a long time.  On occasion, this can lead some employees to avoid change and growth in favor of "the way we've always done things around here."  This resistance to change can sometimes make WellSpan a challenging work environment when you have some employees who embrace change and others who dig in their heels and avoid change.  Also, because employees do tend to stay with WellSpan for a long time (I worked there over 20 years), there is less opportunity for advancement that there would be in a company with a higher turnover rate.

review_title: Many VPs/SVPs suffer from emperor-has-no-clothes syndrome
job_title: Director In Administration in York, PA
pros: Health benefits are solid.
cons:
True innovation at WellSpan is stifled in large part for three reasons:  

1) Homegrown VPs/SVPs responsible for aspects of the business for which they are unprepared.  Leadership recruited from outside of WellSpan and the healthcare industry often encounter resistance and/or passive aggressive hostility when they attempt to implement new processes and programs. Many VPs use their title as currency to prove they know more than their newly hired experts--even if said VP has never had one day of experience in the new hire's area specialty (apparently reading a few articles and throwing around a few buzzwords is enough).     

2) Personality is often prized over performance.  Having alternate opinions than your VP/SVP, even when expressed respectfully and in the context of making smart business decisions often gets you marked as a troublemaker, while those who are overly agreeable (IMO) and reflect the preferred image projected by the VP/SVP are showered with praise, promotions and plum projects.

review_title: I am finally home and amongst peers. Working as one!
pros: I have worked for a handful of healthcare entities in the past and have found myself disappointed and somewhat jaded by my fellow workers in terms of professionalism and overall experience. When I joined Wellspan, I held my breath for months waiting for people to become unlikable or untrustworthy. I have been here for almost a year and I am proud to say just the opposite, nearly every healthcare worker I work with day to day is kind, compassionate, professional, dedicated to thier job. In a word, human. I feel I am with like people, and I do not feel like an outsider working here just because I care about my job. It is said that if everyone brings a dish to the table, we can all eat. I found a feast at Wellspan.
cons: I have a long commute, but it's worth it. If you have been here less than 5 years and work during the daytime, you must park a few blocks away and take a shuttle in. For the job, even that is worth it. I wish I was paid more for my level of responsibility, but I believe (for my particular accolades, YMMV) you are paid according to your credentials and not the demands of the job itself.

pros: Great benefits, offers competitive pay
cons:

No weekend differential

review_title: Not worth having ideas or opinions, they won't listen
pros: Benefits are pretty decent, health care cheap and thorough as long as you stay in network.  Time off benefits about average, though being able to take the time off in a higher level position was difficult.  Growing and dominating the market, they're not going anywhere, so no worries about being bought out.
cons: Cheap!  They don't pay anyone to market rates except the top dogs.  At least 20-30% less salary than Baltimore County, MD for the work-a-day folks.  That includes doctors, you're going to be well under the 50th percentile with above median hours/coverage expected.  Also a strange culture, they are more concerned with marketing themselves and their brand name versus actual quality and high levels of performance.  The C-suite folks think they can do no wrong, so if you're not one of them you are wasting time and energy having an opinion.

pros:
Beautiful, well supported Cancer Center 
Job Security
Strong Rad Onc group
cons:
Corporate Medicine
Meetings valued so highly that our pay is based on meeting attendance, and meetings are held to allow us to achieve our meeting requirements 
Leadership isn’t clear.  Wellspan prides itself on “the matrix”, which has 3 parts: Local hospital, medical group (clinicians), and service lines.  This arrangement results in everyone passing the buck, and no one taking responsibility.

review_title: Lack of basic business management skills; frustrating place to work
pros: Benefits are great.  Access to and coverage of basic and specialty healthcare services is very good.  Extras like free massages and accupuncture are great.  Good matching for retirement accounts.
cons: Everyone works 2-3 FTEs worth of responsibilities.  As WellSpan continues to grow, the work to continues to pile on with no acknowledgement (much less compensation) that most managers are already stretched too thin.  Demands for improved quality and volume of work are not accompanied by sound business planning or required resources.  Many leaders in director and higher level positions seem to lack fundamental business skills, which leads me to believe that senior leadership doesn't get it either since they keep promoting these people.

pros: Sufficient benefits package and competitive wage rates
cons: Very weak management. Examples of poor leadership that I have personally witnessed: managers committing rampant time theft by altering their attendance records, overt favoritism, taking credit for staff's ideas when they had insulted them in private, and assigning punitive measures and corrective action for known mental disabilities to discourage the employee enough to quit.

review_title: The WORST experience of my career!
pros: Good benefits and pay was initially good. Offsite facility where I worked was conveniently located and had modern features.
cons: The so-called management professional for my team outwardly showed favoritism and had a huge ego that needed to be stroked constantly by staff.  Those on the team who were not well-liked were those who did not focus their attention on the manager and their boring, and at times, crude and inappropriate discussions about their personal life during team meetings. If you enjoy a position where you cannot have independent thoughts or ideas, enjoy extreme micromanagement as well as the potential for belittlement during meetings, then this is the place to go. The division where I worked definitely had a “boy’s club” mentality so if you are a female you should do twice the work, go without recognition, and usually have some type of criticism thrown in for a little boost of morale.  There were masked repercussions related to employee satisfaction surveys as well.  This was the absolute worst, demoralizing, arrogant, self-serving manage, team, company that I worked for in my career and I would never recommend this healthcare system to a friend or family member.

review_title: Work somewhere else if you can
pros: Health benefits and 401k matching
cons:
An overwhelming number of the org’s key leadership (HR, Finance, IT, Med Group, PR/Planning, Operations) has been with WellSpan for 20+ years.  New leaders to the organization are recruited to spur on change and innovation but are overwhelmingly shut down after a year or two by the old guard who don’t trust anyone but themselves. Lots of mediocre minds are coddled and promoted by playing along with the Stepford-esque “culture” leadership promotes. Healthy debate is viewed as too confrontational. Group consensus is more than not the norm. They like to say the org works as a matrix but so many departments are control and command. 

HR’s stated compensation strategy is to pay not higher than the 50th percentile. It’s a great way to lose out on top talent and hire mediocre staff. Penny wise and pound foolish. In the last couple of years they’ve started to offer sign-on bonuses for nurses and other critical positions. Problem is they waited until the situation was dire.

review_title: Loved the job but, hated the office politics.
pros: The best insurance around. The benefits are the best.
cons: Too much favoritism, if you're not in the click, you're not really part of the team. Salaries are not the best. Not much appreciation shown unless you're in the "click" Never have I had so much controversy with a group of co-workers in my life! The "go to people" who were in charge when the supervisor wasn't present were the worst, they talked about the other co-workers, was unfair and not professional at all. No respect was had. It was a joke. Thankless.

review_title: Excellent benefits but growing too quickly
job_title: Registered Nurse in Spring Grove, PA
pros: Benefits, compensation, caring and hard-working nurses. Great interdisciplinary environment. Doctors respect nurses more than at other facilities.
cons: Rapidly growing and promoting from outside rather than from within. Do more to keep the staff you have as they are the backbone of the company.

pros: Benefits are fantastic. 401k match, Health/vision/dental and different tier system options. Generous PTO plan and opportunities for continuing education credits.
cons: Leadership and individuals on the top are treated great, the rest of the staff are just a number. Limited opportunity for career advancement and no flexibility with schedule if needed.

job_title: Physician Office Assistant in York, PA
pros: Doctors are great...however they are shielded from what actually goes on in their practice from horrible managment. Are you someone with absolutely no regard for others who will do anything to climb the ranks? This is the place for you!
cons: Everything. Managment is inexperienced, unqualified, and completely unprofessional. Extremely hostile work enviroment which is made worse by dictator like managment. You cannot bring up any issues you have with managment's uneducated decision making or there will be extreme reprocussions. They will fire great employees based on just the word of one awful one. Guilty until proven innocent...and no one is ever proven innocent. Your job will not ever be secure if you are a decent person. Most people transfer after 6 months. Good luck finding many people who have worked there more than a few years.turn over rate is at am all time high thanks to the latest "manager" who has absolutely no idea how am my thing works is only present to condescend and treat people as if they were her misbehaving children that she resents having. Save yourself years off your life. Run. Don't walk.

pros: Management is wonderful!!  The company leadership is very committed to making this a company that really does work as one to improve patient care and I feel as if they really do care about the patient's that they care for and also for their employees.  Benefits are great for employees!!!
cons: I really have not experienced any cons while working for this company.  The work schedule can increase at times of high patient census, but that is really to be expected in order to give excellent patient care with medical records that are ready and up-to-date for caregivers to review when making medical decisions for their patients.

job_title: Food Service Worker in Red Lion, PA
pros:
For a part-time, entry-level job, the benefits at this company are FANTASTIC!
Company minimum wage is 10.50 per hour. If you work even one minute after 7pm you get the evening rate of 11.55 for your entire shift. 403b retirement, health insurance, life insurance, EDUCATION benefits, FREE MASSAGES, and a lot of other crap too!
cons: For any of the Service and Trade departments, what little training you receive is not very good. Nobody here knows how to work as a team to get things done, or to provide quality service. All that people care about is what they have to do to leave as soon as possible. In healthcare, or any patient care oriented work environment, that is just unacceptable.

review_title: I work here only because of the location, otherwise I would not recommend it.

cons: It is very cliquey and I do not feel that the nursing practice keeps up with best practice for patient care. If the group you work with does not like you, then you are doomed. I have managed to try to keep my distance from the clique in my unit and I have been OK. But I have seen other nice and competent workers come and go because false statements were made. There are a few nurses who have actually fabricated complaints about others. It does not seem to be addressed here.

I love what I do so I'm motivated to get the job done but it would be nice to see a paycheck that reflects the time I actually put in.

review_title: Quality non-profit health system understaffed and hospitalist group underpaid
pros: Well-integrated, non-profit health system. Consistently rated as a top -100 hospital in the USA. Very good benefits package. Comprehensive, state-of-the-art services at York Hospital. Great nursing staff.
cons: The larger it gets, the less personal it becomes. Chronically understaffed in all areas, including nursing and hospitalists. An increasing disconnect between physicians and administration. Salaries for hospitalists are not attractive enough to recruit or retain good physicians. The productivity bonuses are becoming more difficult to achieve because of unattainable quality parameters such as patient satisfaction.

review_title: A very good place to work
pros: Wellspan is committed to giving back to the community.  It recognizes the importance of remaining competitive to hire the best.  The organization provides a solid benefit package.  The location is near Baltimore which provides more cultural opportunities.
cons: The organization is currently very interested in developing a very large cash reserve in order to maintain its high bond rating.  This is clearly a mixed bag but it does limit the current capital available for new projects.  On the other hand, it will help provide for the long term viability of the organization.

review_title: Could be worse, Could be better.
job_title: IT Operations Analyst in Red Lion, PA
pros:
Working in the Data Center Operations group for a number of years my co-workers were great people, and supervisors were fair. Constantly learning something new. Casual environment. 
Health benefits are fantastic as long as you use an in network provider. Growing and constantly working to keep up with current technologies.
cons: There are no consistent skill levels or expectations of co-workers. If you were skilled and made a mistake the manager would come down hard, if you were relatively low skill and did so, rarely a word was said. Lack of communications between the different IT areas was lacking. It was almost impossible to move from the IT Operations area into a more technical area.

pros: The Benefits are very good.
cons: Wellspan is to large of a company.  They don't care about their employees as a person but look at the employees as a number.  A number that will bring in more money.  The bottom line is about all they care about.  It's a toxic environment to work in and employee harassment is very prevalent.  And nothing is ever done about the harassment.  Managers only care if the employees are making them look good.  Not if their employees are happy with their working environment.

job_title: Manager-Central Sterile Processing in York, PA
pros: This is by far the most collaborative work environment I have seen.  Usually, we deal with a lot of blaming back and forth that only serves to make work much more stressful while doing nothing to help our patients.  Here, I do not have to deal with that.  What a refreshing change!
cons: The opportunities for advancement are limited.  Often, they post a job and will not consider fully qualified applicants because they already have someone in mind.  If you do not happen to be that one person, your qualifications will not even get you an interview.

WellSpan had virtually NO COMPETITION for over 40 years and was caught totally asleep at the wheel while UPMC parked itself right in its front yard and is now left scrambling! This health system will be merged into a larger system in 5 years and all the administrators will get their payday at the expense of the providers and patients!  DO NOT BECOME AN EMPLOYED PHYSICIAN OF THIS SYSTEM!!

pros: Friendly caring group of people. Good benefits and very flexible.
cons: They don't value the good employees enough, they keep a lot of bad and don't try to keep the good ones.

pros: Great health insurance. Good pto, and retirement benefits.
cons: Management is seriously lacking. I found the workplace to be extremely clique-y, not very warm to "outsiders". Staff was EXTREMELY judgmental to the certain patients, therefore affecting the care that was provided to them. Nursing assistants were performing tests and procedures that were COMPLETELY out of their scope. My position was a new one to the particular office, and the orientation was sub par.

review_title: It was a good learning opportunity for me, as a leader.  However, the company was not committed to the employees.
pros: Gave me vast experience due to the diversified business model.
cons: Executive and senior leaders do not have realistic vision of challenges and are not open to views outside of their own.

pros: This is an amazing company to work for because of the people. They are always pleasant and helpful regardless of your stress at the moment. Managers have your back, support and team work has been unprecedented in my career thus far.
cons: It is a large organization and sometimes things fall through the cracks despite the best processes actively put in place. Humans make mistakes anywhere you go.

review_title: Please don't apply here.  Company is dishonest about compensation potential.  Lower income than you can make elsewhere.
pros: Good benefits.  Patients are great. Company is definitely having growing pains.
cons: They advertise low physician turnover but that is simply not true. Very high turnover. Low morale. Lack of respect for physicians at every level from the office managers to nursing staff to administration. Poor leadership. Drastically changed compensation plan with 1 week notice.

review_title: Terrible place to work with arrogant, overpaid senior leadership
pros: Wellspan has a very good benefits package for its employees. It is affordable and gives plenty of options when selecting physicians.
cons: Everything else!  As part of leadership team for nearly two years, I saw corporate greed at its worst.  Employees are treated unfairly and are grossly underpaid.  Certain staff (techs) are generally seen as second-class citizens.  Pressure is placed on leadership to meet unrealistic budget goals which can only be accomplished by cutting staff or purchasing cheap medical supplies that put patients at risk for infections.  I made the worst career decision of my life by leaving another healthcare system to work for this joke of a company.

review_title: Very difficult place to work if you like people and value patients and want to see them do well
pros: The benefits package is awesome - but I recently started getting collections notices in the mail for things that should have been sent to my insurance. I called the insurance company and they said they didn't accept the bill because there was a form missing that I didn't know about (because, telepathy?) So wellspan can't even get that right.
cons:
1- Management and leadership home grown from wellspan who are uneducated, not qualified, and incompetent. Any other viewpoint is seen as a threat and vehemently opposed. They then spend huge amounts of energy to protect themselves and save their ego while patients continue being hurt. No home grown wellspanner ever gets fired - they waste obscene amounts of money creating positions and moving people around to keep the incompetent protected. The best way to get promoted here is to disastrously fail at the job you are currently doing. 

2- Patient care is atrocious and they care more about their own feelings/egos than doing the right thing. Providers are protected to a fault and celebrated for giving dangerous care. Nursing has no voice and are at a loss on the front lines watching harm happen and unable to do anything about it. Nurses are miserable, have no support, and their care and attitude is a result of this. 

3- If you are an outsider, there is a target on you. If you are a minority or woman, forget it.

pros: Pay and benefits are ok...Because management is so horrible, the 'grunts' develop a high degree of cohesiveness.  I have made many close friends
cons:
IT folks are Micro Managed to a level that is nearly indescribable.

pros: York Hospital employees were very friendly, it was an enjoyable atmosphere.
cons: Being managed by the Billing/Customer Service Dept. (which is located at a separate office building) This department is run my managers who do not care about their employees.  Once I was hired I had found out that my position had been a revolving door.  I was encouraged to communicate any problems or concerns I had, that former employees failed to do so which led to their poor performance.  Early on I noticed serious operational problems with the position and I brought this up as soon as appropriate.  I was initially praised, then thrown under a bus.  I found out that my issues and concerns had been brought up before, yet nothing was done to make improvements. The empty promises of having an office assistant and workers at other office locations to help with the case load was soon followed by threats of termination.  The department threatens all employees with termination to manipulate them into taking on as much work as they feel necessary.  One way they do this is by extending probationary periods for new employees, so that can can hang fear of termination over their head.  Instead of motivating the employee to work harder and WITH management,  it creates the Us Vs Them mentality and you are just waiting for the other shoe to drop.  You know it's only a matter of time before you are terminated; when it is suitable for the department to cover your position- then placing the burden on other employees.
